Text.p: A region between a curve and the x-axis can represent a quantity such as distance, area, or total accumulated change. To approximate that region, we can divide the interval into narrow rectangles, find the area of each rectangle, and add all the areas together. A Riemann sum is an approximation of the total area under a curve obtained by adding the areas of several rectangles drawn under the curve. Narrower rectangles create a more accurate approximation.
In this lesson, we explore how Riemann sums estimate total change and give some intuition for the limit definition of the definite integral.

Text.p: We will explore the definition of a Riemann sum.

question.p: Suppose c_k are sample points for a function f(x) and \Delta x = \dfrac{b - a}{n}. Then a Riemann sum for f on [a, b] is a sum of the form \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) does not include the width \Delta x, so \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) is not a Riemann sum.
\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \Delta x does not include the function values f \left( c_k \right), so \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \Delta x is not a Riemann sum.

A Riemann sum is a sum of the form \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x that is used to estimate the area under the graph of f on [a, b] using n rectangles with width \Delta x and heights given by the function values at the sample points f \left( c_k \right).

question.p: In a Riemann sum, the sample points c_k are \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

choice.label: any choice of points in the kth subinterval

explanation.p: A Riemann sum allows the sample points c_k to be any choice of points in the kth subinterval. The sample points do not have to follow a pattern or be endpoints of the subintervals.

We can choose the left endpoints as the sample points in a Riemann sum, but the sample points do not always have to be the left endpoints. The sample points do not have to follow a pattern or be endpoints of the subintervals.

We can choose the right endpoints as the sample points in a Riemann sum, but the sample points do not always have to be the right endpoints. The sample points do not have to follow a pattern or be endpoints of the subintervals.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: A Riemann sum is sum of the form \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x where \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} and c_k is any point, called a sample point, in the k^{th} subinterval.
Riemann sums can be used to estimate the area under a curve.

Text.p: A Riemann sum provides an estimate of the total area under a curve. As the number of rectangles increases and the width of each rectangle decreases, the Riemann sum approaches an exact value. A definite integral is the limit of a Riemann sum as the number of rectangles approaches infinity and the rectangle width approaches zero. The definite integral of a function f from a to b is defined by
where \Delta x = \frac{b - a}{n} and c_k is a sample point in the k^{th} subinterval. If the limit exists, the function f is integrable on [a, b].

Text.p: We will explore the definition of the definite integral.

question.p: The definite integral is defined as \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: The indefinite integral, not the definite integral, is defined by \displaystyle \int f(x) \, dx = F(x) + C, where F(x) + C is the family of all antiderivatives of f(x).
The definite integral is defined by \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x where c_1, \ldots, c_n are sample points.
The derivative of f at a, not the definite integral, is defined by f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \dfrac{f(x) - f(a)}{x - a}.

question.p: The definite integral is defined by \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x where c_1, \ldots, c_n are sample points. If the limit exists, we say that f is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} on [a, b].

explanation.p: f is differentiable on [a, b] if f has a unique tangent line at every point in [a, b]. If the limit of Riemann sums exists, f may or may not be differentiable.
f is continuous on [a, b] if \lim_{x \to c} f(x) = f(c) at every point c in [a, b]. If the limit of Riemann sums exists, f may or may not be continuous.
If the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x exists, we can find the definite integral of f from a to b and we say that f is integrable.

The integrand of the integral \displaystyle \int_2^5 x^3 \, dx is defined and finite on the closed, bounded interval [2, 5], so the integral is not improper.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: The definite integral of f from a to b is defined as a limit of Riemann sums: \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x .
If the limit exists, f is integrable on [a,b] .

Text.p: The definite integral of f from a to b is \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x where \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x is a Riemann sum using sample points c_k .

When f is continuous, the limit exists and we can evaluate the definite integral using the limit of any Riemann sum. We may choose the left endpoints, right endpoints, midpoints, or any points within the subintervals as the sample points in the Riemann sum.

choice.explanation: The summation index is the variable k that acts as the counter for the sum.
n is the upper bound of the sum, not the summation index.
1 is the lower bound of the sum, not the summation index.

MultipleChoice.question: \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^2 can be found using the power sum formula \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

choice.explanation: The power sum formula for the first n squares is most appropriate for finding \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^2.
\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^2 is asking for the sum of the first n squares, not the first n integers.
\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^2 is asking for the sum of the first n squares, not the first n cubes.

Text.p: We will explore integrable functions.

question.p: If f is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} on [a, b], then f is integrable on [a, b].

explanation.p: If f is continuous on [a, b], then the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x exists and f is integrable on [a, b].

A piecewise function may be defined on [a, b], but not be integrable on [a, b]. Ex: f(x) = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } x \leq 2 \\ 3 & \text{if } x \gt 2 \end{cases} is defined on [0, 4] but is not integrable on [0, 4] because the jump discontinuity at x = 2 means the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x does not exist.

image.description: Piecewise function <m>f(x)</m> on <m>[0,4]</m> with a jump from <m>y=1</m> to <m>y=3</m> at <m>x=2</m>; not integrable due to discontinuity.

explanation.p: A rational function may be defined on [a, b], but not be integrable on [a, b]. Ex: f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x} is defined on [-2, 2] but is not integrable on [-2, 2] because the vertical asymptote at x = 0 means the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x does not exist.

image.description: Function <m>f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x}</m> on the <m>xy</m>-plane, with a vertical asymptote at <m>x = 0</m> and no critical points.

question.p: The function f(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} is integrable on [0, 3].

explanation.p: f(x) = \begin{cases} -1 & \text{if } x < 1 \\ 2 & \text{if } x \geq 1 \end{cases} is not integrable on [0, 4] because the jump discontinuity at x = 1 means the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x does not exist.

image.description: Piecewise function <m>f(x)</m> on <m>[0,4]</m>: <m>f(x) = -1</m> for <m>x < 1</m>, <m>f(x) = 2</m> for <m>x \geq 1</m>, with a jump discontinuity at <m>x = 1</m>.

explanation.p: x^2 is continuous on [0, 3], so x^2 is integrable on [0, 3].

image.description: Function <m>x^2</m> on the interval <m>[0, 3]</m> in the <m>xy</m>-plane; increasing and concave up, with endpoint values 0 and 9.x^2.

explanation.p: f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x - 1} is not integrable on [0, 3] because the vertical asymptote at x = 1 means the limit \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x does not exist.

image.description: Function <m>f(x) = \dfrac{1}{x-1}</m> on an <m>x</m>-<m>y</m> plane, with a vertical asymptote at <m>x = 1</m>.

MultipleChoice.question:
The definite integral \displaystyle \int_0^1 x^3 \, dx can be written as the limit of a Riemann sum with
subinterval width \Delta x = \dfrac{1}{n},
sample points c_k = \dfrac{k}{n}, and
function f(x) = x^3,
so that
\displaystyle \int_0^1 x^3 \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: Substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{k}{n} into f(x) = x^3 gives f \left( c_k \right) = \left( \dfrac{k}{n} \right)^3, not \left( \dfrac{k}{n} \right).

This expression is the result of substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{1}{n} into f(x) = x^3 and \dfrac{k}{n} in for \Delta x. However, we want to substitute x = c_k = \dfrac{k}{n} into f(x) = x^3 and \dfrac{1}{n} in for \Delta x.

Substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{k}{n} into f(x) = x^3 gives f \left( c_k \right) = \left( \dfrac{k}{n} \right)^3. Substituting f \left( c_k \right) = \left( \dfrac{k}{n} \right)^3 and \Delta x = \dfrac{1}{n} into the Riemann sum gives \displaystyle \int_0^1 x^3 \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{k}{n} \right)^3 \left( \dfrac{1}{n} \right).

question.p: The Riemann sum can be written as \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: The sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2}{n} \right) does not include f \left( c_k \right) = \dfrac{2k}{n}.

Substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{2k}{n} into f(x) = x gives f \left( c_k \right) = \dfrac{2k}{n}. Substituting f \left( c_k \right) = \dfrac{2k}{n} and \Delta x = \dfrac{2}{n} into the Riemann sum gives \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2k}{n} \right) \left( \dfrac{2}{n} \right).
The sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2k}{n} \right) does not include \Delta x = \dfrac{2}{n}.

question.p: The constant multiple property \displaystyle \sum_{k=m}^n C a_k = C \displaystyle \sum_{k=m}^n a_k can be used to rewrite the sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2k}{n} \right) \left( \dfrac{2}{n} \right) as \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: Using the constant multiple property to move the constants 4 and \dfrac{1}{n^2} to the front of the sum, \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2k}{n} \right) \left( \dfrac{2}{n} \right) = \dfrac{4}{n^2} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k.
k is the summation index, so k is not a constant that can be moved outside of the sum.
k is the summation index, so k is not a constant that can be moved outside of the sum.
The constants in the sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{2k}{n} \right) \left( \dfrac{2}{n} \right) are 4 and \dfrac{1}{n^2}, not n^2.

question.p: Previously, we rewrote the Riemann sum as \dfrac{4}{n^2} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k. The power sum formula that can be used for the remaining sum is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^3 = \dfrac{n^2(n + 1)^2}{4} is the formula for the sum of the first n cubes. However, \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k is asking for the sum of the first n positive integers.
The sum formula for the first n integers is most appropriate for calculating \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k.

\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k^2 = \dfrac{n(n + 1)(2n + 1)}{6} is the formula for the sum of the first n squares. However, \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k is asking for the sum of the first n positive integers.

question.p: The power sum formula \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k = \dfrac{n(n + 1)}{2} can be used to rewrite \dfrac{4}{n^2} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n k as \dfrac{4}{n^2} \dfrac{n(n + 1)}{2} = \dfrac{4n^2 + 4n}{2n^2}. Taking the limit as n goes to infinity, \displaystyle \int_0^2 x \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{4n^2 + 4n}{2n^2} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: The limit at infinity of a rational function like \dfrac{4n^2 + 4n}{2n^2} is determined by the leading terms in the numerator and denominator.
The leading term in the numerator is 4n^2 and the leading term in the denominator is 2n^2.

CorrectExplanation.p: The limit at infinity of a rational function is determined by the leading terms in the numerator and denominator, so
Using the limit, \displaystyle \int_0^2 x \, dx = 2.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: If f is continuous on [a,b], then f is integrable on [a,b].
We can evaluate the definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx using the limit of a Riemann sum \displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x.

Activity.title: The definite integral and area under a curve

Text.p: The definite integral of f from a to b is defined as the limit of Riemann sums: \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x If f(x) \geq 0 , as n increases, the sum gets closer to the exact area under the graph of f on [a, b] .

image.description: <m>f(x)</m> on <m>[a, b]</m> with shaded area under curve; left shows Riemann sum, right shows exact definite integral as <m>n</m> increases.

ArcResource.title: The definite integral and area under a curve

ShortAnswer.question: The area of a triangle with base b=8 and height h=8 is \frac{1}{2}bh = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The area of a triangle with base b=8 and height h=8 is \frac{1}{2}bh = \frac{1}{2}(8)(8) = \frac{1}{2}(64) = 32.

Hints.hint: Substitute b=8 and height h=8 into \frac{1}{2}bh
Compute \frac{1}{2}(8)(8).

Text.p: We explore the relationship between the definite integral and area.

question.p: When f(x) \geq 0 the definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} area under the graph of f.

explanation.p: Each Riemann sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x provides an estimate for the area under the graph of f. However, the definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x is more accurate than an estimate for the area.

The definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives the exact area under the graph of f. As the number of subintervals increases, the estimate \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x approaches the exact area under the graph of f.

question.p: When f(x) \geq 0, the definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives the exact area under the graph of f on the interval [ \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}, \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} ].

choice.label: a, b
choice.explanation: The limits of integration determine the interval. a is the lower limit and b is the upper limit, so the interval is [a, b].

choice.label: b, a
choice.explanation: This reverses the limits. The interval must match the direction of integration, which is from a to b.

choice.label: 0, b
choice.explanation: The lower limit is a, not necessarily 0. The interval should match the bounds of the integral exactly.

question.p: Then \displaystyle \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: f(x) \geq 0, so the definite integral \displaystyle \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx is the area under the graph of f on [0,6].
The area under the graph is the sum of the areas of the triangle and the rectangle.

CorrectExplanation.p: f(x) \geq 0, so the definite integral \displaystyle \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx is the area under the graph of f on [0,6] which is the sum of the areas of the triangle and the rectangle. So \displaystyle \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx = 18 + 12 = 30.

Text.p: We will explore some properties of the definite integral.

question.p: Property 1: \displaystyle \int_a^a f(x) \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

image.description: Function <m>f(x)</m> with the definite integral <m>\int_a^a f(x)\,dx</m> shown as a vertical line at <m>x = a</m>; area is zero.

hint.p: If the limits of integration are both a, \displaystyle \int_a^a f(x) \, dx is a rectangle with width equal to 0.

CorrectExplanation.p: If the limits of integration are both a, \displaystyle \int_a^a f(x) \, dx is a rectangle with width equal to 0 and the net signed area is 0.

question.p: Property 2: \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = - \displaystyle \int_b^a f(x) \, dx. Use property 2 to rewrite the integral: \displaystyle \int_2^6 x^3 \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: If the limits of integration are reversed, the integral is multiplied by -1. The negative sign is missing in \displaystyle \int_6^2 x^3 \, dx.
Property 2 is used when the limits of integration are reversed. The limits have not been reversed in -\displaystyle \int_2^6 x^3 \, dx .
Property 2 shows that if the limits of integration are reversed, the integral is multiplied by -1, so \displaystyle \int_2^6 x^3 \, dx = - \displaystyle \int_6^2 x^3 \, dx.

list.item: Property 3: \displaystyle \int_a^b \left[ f(x) + g(x) \right] \, dx = \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx + \displaystyle \int_a^b g(x) \, dx.
Property 4: \displaystyle \int_a^b \left[ f(x) - g(x) \right] \, dx = \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx - \displaystyle \int_a^b g(x) \, dx.
Property 5: \displaystyle \int_a^b c f(x) \, dx = c \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx for a constant c.

question.p: Use properties 3, 4, and 5 to rewrite the integral: \displaystyle \int_0^1 3x^2 - 4x + 9 \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: x is the variable of integration, not a constant that can be moved to the front of the integral.
Properties 3, 4, and 5 allow us to separate integrals of sums and differences and move constants to the front of the integral. Using these three properties,

The sign between terms is the same before and after separating integrals using properties 3 and 4. The signs have changed between the original integral and 3 \displaystyle \int_0^1 x^2 \, dx + 4 \displaystyle \int_0^1 x \, dx - 9\displaystyle \int_0^1 1 \, dx.

question.p: Property 6: \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \displaystyle \int_a^c f(x) \, dx + \displaystyle \int_c^b f(x) \, dx for any a \leq c \leq b. A visual representation of property 6 is given by \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

image.description: Integral region on the <m>xy</m>-plane showing area under <m>f(x)</m> from <m>a</m> to <m>b</m>, split at <m>c</m> into two colored subregions.

explanation.p: Property 6 can be visualized by showing the area between f and the x-axis on [a, b] as the sum of the area on [a, c] and the net signed area on [c,b].

image.description: Constant function <m>f(x)</m> with a vertical segment from <m>(a, 0)</m> to <m>(a, f(x))</m> on the <m>x</m>-<m>y</m> coordinate plane.

explanation.p: Property 6 can be visualized by showing the area between f and the x-axis on [a, b] is a sum of two areas. This figure has only one area and visualizes property 1.

image.description: Integral region between a parabola and a line on the <m>xy</m>-plane, shaded from <m>x = a</m> to <m>x = b</m>.

explanation.p: Property 6 can be visualized by showing the area between f and the x-axis on [a, b] is a sum of two areas. This figure shows the area between two functions, not the sum of two areas.

TextResource.Text: Lesson Summary If f(x) \geq 0 and f is integrable on [a,b] , then the area under the graph of f over [a,b] is given by \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x

Text.p: If f(x) \geq 0, then the exact area under the graph of f on [a, b] is given by \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx.
If f instead takes on both positive and negative values, the definite integral gives the net signed area, which is the total area above the x-axis minus the total area below the x-axis. Formally,

p.definition: the net signed area between the graph of f and the x -axis over [a,b] is A_+ - A_- , where A_+ is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie above the x -axis and A_- is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie below the x -axis

image.description: Function <m>f(x)</m> on Cartesian axes, showing area <m>A_+</m> above the x-axis and <m>A_</m> below, over interval <m>[a, b]</m>.

MultipleChoice.question: The net signed area under f(x) over [0,3] is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

choice.label: negative
choice.explanation: The net signed area is the negative value -\frac{1}{2}.

choice.label: positive
choice.explanation: The net signed area would be positive if the area above the x-axis was greater than the area below the x-axis. Here the area of the region below the x-axis is greater.

choice.label: zero
choice.explanation: The net signed area would be zero if the area above the x-axis was equal to the area below the x-axis. Here the area of the region below the x-axis is greater.

The definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives the net signed area between the graph of f and the x-axis. A_+ + A_- is the total area, not the net signed area.
The definite integral \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives the net signed area. (A_+)(A_-) is not an area between the graph of f and the x-axis.

explanation.p: A_+ + A_- is the total area, not the net signed area.

So \displaystyle \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx = \dfrac{3}{2} \pi.

So the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie below the x-axis is A_- = 6.

question.p: Previously we found A_+ = 3 and A_- = 6. The net signed area between the graph of f and the x-axis over [-2, 5] is \displaystyle \int_{-2}^5 f(x) \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: The net signed area between the graph of f and the x -axis over [a,b] is \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = A_+ - A_- where A_+ is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie above the x -axis and A_- is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie below the x -axis.
The net signed area is positive if the A_+ is greater than A_- , negative if the A_+ is less than A_- , and zero if the A_+ is equal to A_- .

Text.p: If v(t) is the velocity of an object at time t and we want to find the total distance the object travelled, regardless of direction, we use \displaystyle \int_a^b \left| v(t) \right| \, dt. The absolute value ensures that both directions of travel count positively toward the total distance. More generally,

p.definition: the total area under the graph of f on [a,b] is \displaystyle \int_a^b \left| f(x) \right| \, dx , which adds up the area of all regions above and below the x -axis. So the total area is A_+ + A_- , where A_+ is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie above the x -axis and A_- is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie below the x -axis.

ShortAnswer.question: If A_+ = \frac{1}{2} and A_- = 1, the total area is A_+ + A_- = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The total area is the sum of all areas above and below the x-axis, A_+ + A_- = \frac{1}{2} + 1 = \frac{3}{2}.

Hints.hint: Add A_+ and A_- to find the total area.
The total area is \dfrac{1}{2} + 1.

question.p: Consider function f that is integrable on [a,b] with

explanation.p: The definite integral of f(x) gives the net signed area between the graph of f and the x-axis over [a,b], not the total area.
The total area between the graph of f and the x-axis over [a,b] is the sum of the areas of all the regions (above and below the x-axis), which is not the same as \left| A_+ - A_- \right|.

image.description: Integral region on xy-plane showing <m>A_+ = 2</m> above the x-axis from <m>x = 0</m> to <m>2</m> and <m>A_- = 1</m> below from <m>x = 2</m> to <m>3</m>.

explanation.p: A_+ + A_- = 2 + 1 = 3 \neq \left| A_+ - A_- \right| = \left| 2 - 1 \right| = 1.

The total area between the graph of f and the x-axis over [a,b] is the sum of the areas of all the regions (above and below the x-axis). So the total area is A_+ + A_- = \displaystyle \int_a^b \left| f(x) \right| \, dx.

Text.p: A car travels directly east at 60 mph for 4 hours. The car then turns around and travels directly west at 80 mph for 3 hours. A graph of the car's velocity, v(t) at time t is given by

question.p: The distance travelled east by the car during the first four hours is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie above the t-axis: A_+ = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} miles.

A_+ is the area of the rectangle in the figure.

CorrectExplanation.p: A_+ is the area between the graph of v and the t-axis on [0,4], which is the area of a rectangle with width 4 and height 60. So A_+ = 4(60) = 240.

A_- is the area of the rectangle in the figure.

image.description: Velocity <m>v(t)</m> versus time <m>t</m> with a shaded rectangle <m>A_-</m> from <m>t = 4</m> to <m>t = 7</m>, <m>v(t) = -80</m>.

CorrectExplanation.p: A_- is the area between the graph of v and the t-axis on [4, 7], which is the area of a rectangle with width 3 and height 80. So A_- = 3(80) = 240.

image.description: Velocity <m>v(t)</m> versus time <m>t</m> with a shaded rectangle <m>A_-</m> from <m>t = 4</m> to <m>t = 7</m>, <m>v(t) = -80</m>.

question.p: Previously we found A_+ = 240 and A_- = 240. The displacement of the car between times t = 0 and t = 7 hours is \displaystyle \int_0^7 v(t) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} miles.

hint.p: Use \displaystyle \int_0^7 v(t) \, dt = A_+ - A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: Using \displaystyle \int_0^7 v(t) \, dt is the net signed area,
So the displacement of the car between t = 0 and t = 7 hours is 0 miles. That is, the car started and ended the drive at the same location.

question.p: Previously we found A_+ = 240, A_- = 240, and the car's displacement. Now we will find the distance travelled by the car. The total distance travelled by the car between times t = 0 and t = 7 hours is \displaystyle \int_0^7 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} miles.

hint.p: Use \displaystyle \int_0^7 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt = A_+ + A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: Using \displaystyle \int_0^7 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt is the total area,
So, the total distance travelled by the car between t = 0 and t = 7 hours is 480 miles.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: The total area between the graph of f and the x -axis over [a,b] is \displaystyle \int_a^b \left| f(x) \right| \, dx = A_+ + A_- where A_+ is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie above the x -axis and A_- is the total sum of the areas of all regions that lie below the x -axis.
The total area is always positive.

Activity.title: The average value of a function

Text.p: We find the average of n numbers x_1, x_2,...,x_n using \frac{1}{n}\left( x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n \right). Ex: The average of the four numbers 2, 5, 6, and 7 is \frac{1}{4} (2+5+6+7) =5. This averaging method works well for any finite set of numbers, such as exam scores or monthly utility bills.

However, sometimes we want the average of a quantity that changes continuously, like the temperature throughout the day or the velocity of a car. We will need a definite integral to find averages of continuous functions. The average value of a continuous function f on [a,b] is \frac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx.

ArcResource.title: The average value of a function

ShortAnswer.question: The average of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.
ShortAnswer.CorrectExplanation: The average of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 is \frac{1}{5}(1+2+3+4+5)= \frac{1}{5}(15) = 3.

Hints.hint: Find the sum 1+2+3+4+5.
Divide the total 15 by 5 to get the average.

Text.p: We will explore the definition of the average value of a function.

question.p: A formula for the average value of the continuous function f on the interval [a,b] is f_{avg} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n c_k provides an estimate for the average value of f, but cannot be used to find the average value.
The average value of the function f on the interval [a,b] is f_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx.

\dfrac{1}{n} \left( f \left( c_1 \right) + \cdots + f \left( c_n \right) \right) is the average of the function value at a finite number of points c_1, \ldots, c_n. f is a continuous function, so the average must consider all the infinitely many function values for f.

question.p: The average value of the function f on the interval [a,b] is f_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx. \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of the function f(x) = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Hints.hint: \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of the integrand of \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx.

CorrectExplanation.p: \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of the integrand f(x) = x^3 of \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx.

question.p: The average value of the function f on the interval [a,b] is f_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx. The expression \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of f on the interval [0, \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}].

Hints.hint: \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of f on the interval [a, b] where a is the lower limit and b is the upper limit of \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx.

CorrectExplanation.p: \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx gives the average value of f on the interval [0, 2] where a = 0 is the lower limit and b = 2 is the upper limit of \displaystyle \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx.

Text.p: We will find the average value of f(x) = x^2 on [0, 3].

question.p: The average value of the function f(x) = x^2 on the interval [0,3] is f_{avg} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: The formula for the average value includes the constant \dfrac{1}{b-a} in front of the integral. \dfrac{1}{b-a} is missing in \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx.
The formula for the average value includes the constant \dfrac{1}{b-a} in front of the integral, not \dfrac{1}{f(b) - f(a)}.
Substituting f(x) = x^2, a = 0, and b = 3 into \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx gives f_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{3} \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx.

question.p: Using \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = 9, the average value of f(x) = x^2 on [0, 3] is \dfrac{1}{3} \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Hints.hint: Substitute \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = 9 into \dfrac{1}{3} \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx.

CorrectExplanation.p: Substituting \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = 9 into \dfrac{1}{3} \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx gives \dfrac{1}{3} \displaystyle \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = \dfrac{1}{3} \cdot 9 = 3. So the average value of f(x) = x^2 on [0, 3] is 3.

Text.p: We will find the average velocity between t = 0 and t = 5 hours of a car travelling with velocity v(t) = \begin{cases} 30 & \text{if } t \leq 3 \\ 10t & \text{if } t \gt 3 \end{cases} mph.

image.description: Piecewise velocity <m>v(t)</m>: constant at 30 for <m>0 \leq t \leq 3</m>, then increasing linearly to 50 at <m>t = 5</m>; axes are <m>t</m> and <m>v(t)</m>.

question.p: The average value of the function v(t) on the interval [0,5] is v_{avg} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt.

Hints.hint: The average value of the function v(t) on the interval [a,b] is v_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b v(t) \, dt.
Use a = 0 and b = 5 to find \dfrac{1}{b-a}.

CorrectExplanation.p: The average value of the function v(t) on the interval [0,5] is v_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b v(t) \, dt = \dfrac{1}{5-0} \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt.

question.p: Using the property \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = \displaystyle \int_a^c f(x) \, dx + \displaystyle \int_c^b f(x) \, dx and the piecewise definition of v(t), \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

explanation.p: The piecewise defined function v(t) changes behavior at c = 3. v(t) = 30 for t \leq 3 and v(t) = 10t for t \gt 3. Using the definite integral property to break the integral into two integrals at c = 3, v(t) = 30 on [0, 3] and v(t) = 10t on [3, 5], \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt.
The integral property splits the interval into two intervals, [0, c] and [c, 5]. The piecewise defined function v(t) changes behavior at c = 3, so the interval of integration can be split at c = 3.
The limits of integration are appropriate, but the integrands are reversed. The piecewise definition of v(t) shows v(t) = 30 on [0, 3] and v(t) = 10t on [3, 5].

question.p: \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Hints.hint: \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt is the net signed area between the graph of v(t) and the t-axis on the interval [0, 3].

\displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt is the area of the rectangle in the figure
Function <m>v(t)</m> on a coordinate plane; constant at 30 for <m>0 \leq t \leq 3</m>, then increasing linearly to 50 at <m>t = 5</m>.

CorrectExplanation.p: \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt is the net signed area between the graph of v(t) and the t-axis on the interval [0, 3], which is a rectangle with width 3 and height 30. So \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt = 3(30) = 90.

image.description: Function <m>v(t)</m> on a coordinate plane; constant at 30 for <m>0 \leq t \leq 3</m>, then increasing linearly to 50 at <m>t = 5</m>.

question.p: \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Hints.hint: \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt is the net signed area between the graph of v(t) and the t-axis on the interval [3, 5].

\displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt is the area of the rectangle plus the area of the triangle in the figure
<m>v(t)</m> on a coordinate plane, constant at 30 for <m>3 \leq t \leq 4</m>, then increasing linearly to 50 at <m>t = 5</m>; shaded integral region shown.

CorrectExplanation.p: \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt is the net signed area between the graph of v(t) and the t-axis on the interval [3, 5], which is the sum of the area of a rectangle with width 2 and height 30 and the area of a triangle with base 2 and height 20. So
So, \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt = 80.

question.p: Previously, we found

list.item: \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt = 90,
\displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt = 80, and
\displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt.

question.p: Then \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

Hints.hint: Substitute \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt = 90 and \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt = 80 into \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt + \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt.

CorrectExplanation.p: Substituting \displaystyle \int_0^3 30 \, dt = 90 and \displaystyle \int_3^5 10t \, dt = 80,
So, \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = 170.

question.p: Previously, we found \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = 170. The average value of the function v(t) on the interval [0,5] is v_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{5} \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} mph.

Hints.hint: Substitute \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = 170 into v_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{5} \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt.

CorrectExplanation.p: Substituting \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = 170,
So, the average velocity of the car between t = 0 and t = 5 hours is 34 mph.

Text.p: Lesson Summary

list.item: The average of n numbers x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n is x_{avg} = \frac{x_1+x_2+\cdots x_n}{n}.
The average value of a continuous function f on [a,b] is f_{avg} = \frac{1}{b-a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx .

Text.p: We identify the limits of integration and the integrand of \displaystyle \int_{-3}^8 x^4 \, dx.

question.p: The lower limit of integration is -3 and the upper limit of integration is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} in the definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-3}^8 x^4 \, dx.

hint.p: The lower limit is located below the integral sign and the upper limit is located above the integral sign.

CorrectExplanation.p: The lower limit a = -3 is located below the integral sign and the upper limit b = 8 is located above the integral sign.

question.p: The integrand in the definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-3}^8 x^4 \, dx is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: The integrand is located between the integral sign and dx.

CorrectExplanation.p: The integrand f(x) = x^4 is located between the integral sign and dx.

Text.p: We will rewrite the definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-2}^{5} x^3 \, dx as a limit of Riemann sums.

question.p: If n subintervals are used in the Riemann sum, the width of each subinterval is \Delta x = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: Use \Delta x = \dfrac{b - a}{n}.

CorrectExplanation.p: Using a = -2 and b = 5,
So the width of each subinterval is \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n}.

question.p: Previously we found \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n}. The right endpoint of the kth subinterval is c_k = k\Delta x = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: Substitute \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n} into k \Delta x to find c_k.

CorrectExplanation.p: The right endpoint of the kth subinterval is
So the right endpoints are c_k = \dfrac{7k}{n}.

question.p: Previously we found \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n} and c_k = \dfrac{7k}{n}. The definite integral \displaystyle \int_{-2}^5 x^3 \, dx can be rewritten as \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: Substitute x = c_k = \dfrac{7k}{n} into f(x) = x^3 to find f \left( c_k \right). Then substitute f \left( c_k \right) and \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n} into \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x.

CorrectExplanation.p: Substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{7k}{n} into f(x) = x^3 gives f \left( c_k \right) = \left( \dfrac{7k}{n} \right)^3. Substituting f \left( c_k \right) = \left( \dfrac{7k}{n} \right)^3 and \Delta x = \dfrac{7}{n} into the Riemann sum gives

Text.p: We will consider \displaystyle \int_0^5 x \, dx. We will find the value of the definite integral using the limit of a Riemann sum with sample points equal to the right endpoints of each subinterval.

question.p: Using n subintervals of equal width \Delta x = \dfrac{5}{n} and right endpoints c_k = \dfrac{5k}{n}, the definite integral \displaystyle \int_0^5 x \, dx can be rewritten as \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x = \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: Substitute x = c_k = \dfrac{5k}{n} into f(x) = x to find f \left( c_k \right). Then substitute f \left( c_k \right) and \Delta x = \dfrac{5}{n} into \lim_{n \to \infty} \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n f \left( c_k \right) \Delta x.

CorrectExplanation.p: Substituting x = c_k = \dfrac{5k}{n} into f(x) = x gives f \left( c_k \right) = \dfrac{5k}{n}. Substituting f \left( c_k \right) = \dfrac{5k}{n} and \Delta x = \dfrac{5}{n} into the Riemann sum gives

question.p: We can use sum properties to rewrite \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^n \left( \dfrac{5k}{n} \right) \left( \dfrac{5}{n} \right) as \dfrac{25n^2 + 25n}{2n^2}. Taking the limit,

hint.p: To find a limit at infinity of a rational function, compare the leading terms.

CorrectExplanation.p: Comparing the leading terms, \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{25n^2 + 25n}{2n^2} = \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{25n^2}{2n^2} = \dfrac{25}{2}. So \displaystyle \int_0^5 x \, dx = \dfrac{25}{2}.

Text.p: The graph of f(x) is given.

image.description: Function <m>f(x)</m> on an <m>x</m>-<m>y</m> coordinate plane; straight line, increasing, no critical points or asymptotes, concave up.f(x) = 2x - 4 on [0, 6]

question.p: The definite integral \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: The definite integral is the net signed area, A_+ - A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: The definite integral is the net signed area, A_+ - A_-. A_+ is the area of a triangle above the x-axis with base 4 and height 8, so A_+ = \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(8) = 16. A_- is the area of a triangle below the x-axis with base 2 and height 4, so A_- = \dfrac{1}{2}(2)(4) = 4. So \int_0^6 f(x) \, dx = A_+ - A_- = 16 - 4 = 12.

question.p: The total area under the graph of f(x) on the interval [0, 6] is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: The total area is \int_0^6 \left| f(x) \right| \, dx = A_+ + A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: The total area is A_+ + A_-. A_+ is the area of a triangle above the x-axis with base 4 and height 8, so A_+ = \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(8) = 16. A_- is the area of a triangle below the x-axis with base 2 and height 4, so A_- = \dfrac{1}{2}(2)(4) = 4. So the total area is \int_0^6 \left| f(x) \right| \, dx = A_+ + A_- = 16 + 4 = 20.

Text.p: A car travels directly north at 50 mph for 3 hours. The car then turns around and travels directly south at 60 mph for 2 hours. A graph of the car's velocity, v(t) at time t is given by

image.description: Velocity <m>v(t)</m> versus time <m>t</m>; <m>v(t) = 50</m> for <m>0 \leq t < 3</m>, <m>v(t) = -60</m> for <m>3 \leq t \leq 5</m>.

question.p: The displacement of the car between times t = 0 and t = 5 hours is \displaystyle \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} miles.

hint.p: The definite integral is the net signed area, A_+ - A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: The definite integral is the net signed area, A_+ - A_-. A_+ is the area of a rectangle above the t-axis with base 3 and height 50, so A_+ = (3)(50) = 150. A_- is the area of a rectangle below the t-axis with base 2 and height 60, so A_- = (2)(60) = 120. So \int_0^5 v(t) \, dt = A_+ - A_- = 150 - 120 = 30. The car ends its drive 30 miles north of where the car began its drive.

question.p: The total distance travelled by the car between times t = 0 and t = 5 hours is \displaystyle \int_0^5 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} miles.

hint.p: The total distance travelled is \int_0^5 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt = A_+ + A_-.

CorrectExplanation.p: The total distance travelled is A_+ + A_-. A_+ is the area of a rectangle above the t-axis with base 3 and height 50, so A_+ = (3)(50) = 150. A_- is the area of a rectangle below the t-axis with base 2 and height 60, so A_- = (2)(60) = 120. So \int_0^5 \left| v(t) \right| \, dt = A_+ + A_- = 150 + 120 = 270.

question.p: Using \displaystyle \int_{#a#}^{#b#} x^{#n#} \, dx = #I# , the average value of f(x) = x^{#n#} on [#a#, #b#] is f_{avg} = \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} .

hint.p: Use f_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b - a} \displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) \, dx to find the average value.

CorrectExplanation.p: The average value of f(x) = x^{#n#} on [#a#, #b#] is

Text.p: A car's velocity (in mph) at time t (in seconds) is given by

image.description: Function <m>v(t)</m> on <m>[0, 8]</m> in the <m>t</m>-<m>v</m> plane, increasing and concave up, with a maximum near <m>t = 8</m>.v(t)

Text.p: We will estimate the area under v(t) on [0, 8] and then estimate the average velocity.

question.p: An estimate for the area under v(t) on [0, 8] using a Riemann sum with n = 4 rectangles with width \Delta x = 2 and sample points c_1 = 1, c_2 = 4, c_3 = 5 and c_4 = 7 is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}}.

hint.p: Use the graph of v(t) to find f(c_1) = f(1), f(c_2) = f(4), f(c_3) = f(5) and f(c_4) = f(7). Then estimate the area under v(t) on [0, 8] using the Riemann sum \displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^4 f(c_k) \Delta x.

CorrectExplanation.p: Using the graph of v(t), f(c_1) = f(1) = 10, f(c_2) = f(4) = 30, f(c_3) = f(5) = 40 and f(c_4) = f(7) = 60. An estimate for the area under v(t) on [0, 8] is given by the Riemann sum
Since the definite integral is the area under the graph, 280 is also an estimate for \displaystyle \int_0^8 v(t) \, dt.

question.p: Previously, we used a Riemann sum to get 280 as an estimate for \displaystyle \int_0^8 v(t) \, dt. Using \displaystyle \int_0^8 v(t) \, dt = 280, the average velocity of the car over [0, 8] is \underline{\phantom{XXXXXX}} mph.

hint.p: Use v_{avg} = \dfrac{1}{b - a} \displaystyle \int_a^b v(t) \, dt to find the average velocity.

CorrectExplanation.p: Using \displaystyle \int_0^8 v(t) \, dt = 280, the average velocity of the car over [0, 8] is
So, the average velocity of the car is 35 mph during the first 8 seconds.
